rComments: Took Computational Phys(S15) and now have taken almost all of the Physics series. I see it as one of the most challenging and practical courses in the major. Onuttom was extremely clear but concise in lectures(info-dense) and I found him to be great at answering most questions. He is tough and I put in A LOT of work(20h/week) but it was rewarding!
He is a great teacher, buy you need to put in the effort as well. He is beyond smart and knows physics better than other professors.

Lectures are tough, but interesting. Onuttom is a tough teacher, but he really really cares for his students. (Especially physics students) He wants to everyone to do well, so go to his office hours and really learn. He is shockingly precise, making very few mistakes, excluding grammatical. Concepts for this class were really tough for me.

Onuttom is one of a kind. He is very precise and hardly makes mistakes. Extremely intelligent, which makes it hard for him to simplify the concepts to the class. He is a tough grader and his tests are quite tough. He is quite open to his students but may be intimidating. Physics and math majors will love him, Engineers may not like his style.
Will expect something more than just average. He is pretty tough in terms of tests, but if you have a good handle by now then you will be fine.
Professor Narayan is an extremely intelligent man but he SHOULD NOT be teaching undergraduates! He sources other texts without telling his students.

I heard plenty of dreadful things about Onuttom before taking the class, but I liked him. He is an excellent lecturer and is very willing to help on conceptual problems, but less so on the homework. He gave hard homework, fair midterms and a difficult final. He expects work from his students, but is also very considerate.

I don't know if everyone else here had the same professor, but Narayan is an all around solid professor.  I wont say that the course was easy, but that is because of the material.  His explanations of the material were usually adequate and when they were not he was open to questions.  His exams were fair.
This prof is very smart and can explain material in a way that makes sense. There is a lot of at home learning that he expects you to do but if you put time in it will be rewarded

AVOID! This class was a struggle every step of the way. He is an ass in office hours, and not helpful in class. He obviously didn't want to be teaching an intro physics class.. He showed it. In the end, the class was highly curved, and some did do well, but it takes A LOT of work with him. Tests are tricky.

If you're taking ANY class with Narayan, buckle up because you're in for a rough ride. His lectures are informative, but he whizzes through the material. Weekly quizzes account for 60% of your grade (lowest was dropped). The final was just disastrous. He never mentioned if he curves the class or not, so your grade is a gray area until you get it.

This was his first time teaching the 5 series, and he sure as heck made it the most difficult thing in the world. Considering that I am an EE major with experience with a bunch of the laws down already, I still thought this was a VERY painful class. (compared to the rest of the 5 series) He doesn't care if you understand the material or not!

THIS GUY IS INCREDIBLE!!!.... at failing students. He is a beast his final examination was nowhere proportional to the work done in class. He makes a problem worth 30% of the final that was mentioned only in passing in the lectures that he never assigned a homework problem on. DO NOT TAKE HIM

I wish he wasnt the only teacher teaching this course. He lectures way too fast and doesnt even use the textbook hw problems. He assigns his own which are way too hard and there is no way to know if youre doing the problem wrong until he gives u back the homework 3 weeks later with a bad grade. Stay away if you can!!!
The horror of this teacher and class is legendary in the physics department.

Survive him if you can, since he's the only one who teaches this class. I really wanted to give him the benefit of the doubt, but he goes way too fast in lecture, is out-right rude and short-tempered during office hours (I lived off the TA), and assigns homework that will take you all week...or longer. At least he thinks we're all EQUALLY stupid...

He's ok. This class was quite a jump from 116A. You start the class with COMPLETELY new material (branch cuts, etc), so you really have to buckle down to get a decent grade. Lectures are on the dry side. He's very approachable and will help you if you're struggling (I know I was).

Narayan might be the worst prof I had at UCSC. His lectures are incomprehensible, and he is useless in office hours. His tests are hard, but not too bad if you have a grasp on the material(few did). I am very good at math, yet for the first time I got tutoring. He was also unwilling to reason with me about my eval(that he didn't even write anyway).
